0.892 | blank3_name_sec1 = HDI Category | blank3_info_sec1 = very high | blank4_name_sec1 = Literacy | blank4_info_sec1 = 81.9 | website = {{URL|chandigarh.nic.in/}} | footnotes = The city of Chandigarh comprises all of the union territory's area }} '''Chandigarh''' is a city and a [[union territory]] in the [[Northern India|northern part]] of [[India]] that serves as the capital of the states of [[Punjab, India|Punjab]] and [[Haryana]] . As a union territory, the city is ruled directly by the [[Government of India|Union Government of India]] and is not part of either state. The city of Chandigarh was the first [[planned city]] in India post-independence in 1947 and was known internationally for its architecture and urban design.[http://business.gov.in/investment_incentives/chandigarh.php Business Portal of India] The master plan of the city was prepared by [[Le Corbusier]], transformed from an earlier plan by the American planner Albert Mayer. Most of the government buildings and housing in the city, however, is designed by the Chandigarh Capital Project Team headed by [[Pierre Jeanneret]], [[Jane Drew]] and [[Maxwell Fry]]. The city tops the list of [[States and territories of India|Indian States and Union Territories]] by per capita income in the country.{{cite news|url=http://www.hindu.com/2008/09/17/stories/2008091755600800.htm |title=Front Page News : Monday, July 26, 2010 |publisher=The Hindu |date= 17 September 2008|accessdate=2010-07-26 |location=Chennai, India}} The city was reported to be the cleanest in India in 2010, based on a national government study,{{cite web|url=http://news.rediff.com/slide-show/2010/may/11/slide-show-1-chandigarh-cleanest-of-all.htm |title=India's cleanest: Where does your city stand?: Rediff.com News |publisher=News.rediff.com |date=13 May 2010 |accessdate=2010-07-26}} and the territory also headed the list of Indian states and territories according to [[Human Development Index]].[http://megplanning.gov.in/MHDR/Human_De.pdf Meghalaya Human Development Report 2008] (p. 23) The metropolitan of Chandigarh-[[Ajitgarh]]-[[Panchkula]] collectively forms a [[Chandigarh Tricity|Tri-city]].{{cite news |last= |first= |date=Jan 6, 2014 |title= Tricity residents to get Emaar MGF’s Central Plaza soon|url=http://www.financialexpress.com/news/tricity-residents-to-get-emaar-mgf-s-central-plaza-soon/1216018 |deadurl= |newspaper= [[The Financial Express (India)|The Financial Express]]|location= |publisher= |archiveurl= |archivedate= |accessdate= }} ==History== After the [[Partition of India]] in 1947, the [[Punjab Province (British India)|former British province of Punjab]] was also split between [[east Punjab]] in India and [[west Punjab]] in Pakistan. The Indian Punjab required a new capital city to replace [[Lahore]], which became part of Pakistan during the partition.[http://www.chandigarh.co.uk/history.html Chandigarh History – History Of Chandigarh India – Origin & History of Chandigarh] The name Chandigarh, meaning "the Fort of Chandi", is derived from [[Chandi Mandir]], an ancient temple devoted to the [[Hindu]] goddess [[Chandi]], near the city in Panchkula.[http://chandigarh.gov.in/knowchd_general.htm The Official Government Website] Chandigarh hosts the largest of Le Corbusier's many ''Open Hand'' sculptures, standing 26 metres high. ''[[Open Hand Monument|The Open Hand (La Main Ouverte)]]'' is a recurring motif in Le Corbusier's architecture, a sign for him of "peace and reconciliation. It is open to give and open to receive." It represents, what Le Corbusier called, the 'Second Machine Age'.[http://books.google.co.uk/books?id=qG-9cwHOcCIC&pg=PA613&lpg=PA613&dq=le+corbusier+%22the+open+hand%22+india+28+feet&source=bl&ots=skcehGAvZf&sig=ThArn1v4m2sl2VRLnLFwzESDiLU&hl=en&sa=X&ei=R_9SUMSCA6Sf0QXJ3oGoAw&ved=0CC4Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=le%20corbusier%20%22the%20open%20hand%22%20india%2028%20feet&f=false ''Frommer's India''] (2010) Pippa de Bruyn, John Wiley & Sons, p613 ISBN 9780470556108 However, two of the six monuments planned in the Capitol Complex which has the High Court, the Assembly and the Secretariat, remain incomplete. These include Geometric Hill and Martyrs Memorial; drawings were made; their execution, however, was never fully accomplished after starting out in 1956.{{cite news|url=http://www.indianexpress.com/news/capitol-complex-as-le-corbusier-wanted-it/635844/ |title=Capitol Complex, as Le Corbusier wanted it, remains incomplete |publisher=Indian Express |date=2010-06-19 |accessdate=2013-07-02}} On 1 November 1966, the newly formed state of [[Haryana]] was carved out of the eastern portion of Punjab, in order to create Haryana as a majority [[Hindi]]-speaking people, while the western portion of Punjab retained a mostly [[Punjabi language]]-speaking majority and remained as the current state of [[Punjab, India|Punjab]]. Chandigarh was located on the border of both states and the states moved to incorporate the city into their respective territories. However, the city of Chandigarh was made into a [[union territory]] to serve as capital of both states.{{cite web|url=http://www.haryana-online.com/History/history_1966-.htm |title=1st November 1966 - Haryana Day - History - Haryana Online - North India |publisher=Haryana Online |date= |accessdate=2013-07-08}} ==Geography and climate== [[Image:Chandigarh Lake.jpg|left|thumb|Sukhna Lake]] Chandigarh is located near the foothills of the [[Sivalik]] range of the [[Himalaya]]s in northwest India. It covers an area of approximately 44.5 sq mi or 114 km². and shares its borders with the states of Haryana and Punjab. The exact cartographic co-ordinates of Chandigarh are {{Coord|30.74|N|76.79|E|}}.[http://www.fallingrain.com/world/IN/5/Chandigarh.html Falling Rain Genomics, Inc – Chandigarh] It has an average elevation of 321 metres (1053 ft). {{climate chart |Chandigarh |3.1|16.4|33 |5.3|20.1|39 |10.4|25.4|30 |15.9|31.5|9 |20.1|35.3|28 |22.4|35.6|145 |20.9|31.0|280 |20.3|29.7|308 |18.8|30.1|133 |14.0|28.8|22 |7.5|24.3|9 |3.7|19.1|22 |source=[http://www.worldweather.org/066/c00526.htm World Weather Information Service] |float=right |clear= }} The surrounding districts are [[Ajitgarh]], [[Patiala]] and [[Roopnagar]] in Punjab, [[Panchkula]] and [[Ambala]] in Haryana. The boundary of the state of [[Himachal Pradesh]] is also minutes away from its north border. Chandigarh has a [[humid subtropical climate]] characterised by a seasonal rhythm: very hot summers, mild winters, unreliable rainfall and great variation in temperature (−1 °C to 46 °C). The average annual rainfall is [http://chandigarh.nic.in/knowchd_general.htm 1110.7 mm]. The city also receives occasional winter rains from the [[Western Disturbance]] originating over the [[Mediterranean Sea]]. Cold winds usually tend to come from the north near [[Shimla]], capital of Himanchal Pradesh and from the state of [[Jammu and Kashmir]], both of which receive their share of snowfall during wintertime. ===Average temperature=== *'''Spring''': The climate remains the most enjoyable part of the year during the spring season (from February-end to early-April). Temperatures vary between (max) 13 °C to 20 °C and (min) 5 °C to 12 °C. *'''Autumn''': In autumn (from September-end to mid November.), the temperature may rise to a maximum of 30 °C. Temperatures usually remain between 10° to 22° in autumn. The minimum temperature is around 6 °C. *'''Summer''': The temperature in summer (from Mid-April to June-end) may rise to a maximum of 44nbsp;°C. Temperatures generally remain between 30 °C to 42 °C . *'''Monsoon''': During monsoon (from early-July to mid-September), Chandigarh receives moderate to heavy rainfall and sometimes heavy to very heavy rainfall (generally during the month of August or September). Usually, the rain bearing monsoon winds blow from south-west/south-east. Mostly, the city receives heavy rain from south (which is mainly a persistent rain) but it generally receives most of its rain during monsoon either from North-west or North-east. Maximum amount of rain received by the city of Chandigrah during monsoon season is 195.5 mm in a single day. *'''Winter''': Winters (November-end to February-end) are mild but it can sometimes get quite chilly in Chandigarh. Average temperatures in the winter remain at (max) 5 °C to 14 °C and (min) -1 °C to 5 °C. Rain usually comes from the west during winters and it is usually a persistent rain for 2–3 days with sometimes hail-storms.The city witnessed bone-numbing chill as the maximum temperature on Monday, 7 January 2013 plunged to a 30-year low to settle at 6.1 degrees Celsius. {{Weather box |location = Chandigarh |metric first = Yes |single line = Yes |temperature colour = pastel |Jan high C = 19.4 |Feb high C = 21.1 |Mar high C = 29.5 |Apr high C = 34.5 |May high C = 42.4 |Jun high C = 44.3 |Jul high C = 35.0 |Aug high C = 32.8 |Sep high C = 29.1 |Oct high C = 28.8 |Nov high C = 19.9 |Dec high C = 18.1 |Jan low C = 3.9 |Feb low C = 5.4 |Mar low C = 10.4 |Apr low C = 14.9 |May low C = 28.2 |Jun low C = 30.9 |Jul low C = 24.0 |Aug low C = 22.3 |Sep low C = 20.8 |Oct low C = 16.0 |Nov low C = 9.5 |Dec low C = 4.7 | Jan rain mm = 46.6 | Feb rain mm = 33.9 | Mar rain mm = 29.3 | Apr rain mm = 11.3 | May rain mm = 24.2 | Jun rain mm = 112.6 | Jul rain mm = 276.3 | Aug rain mm = 282.8 | Sep rain mm = 179.0 | Oct rain mm = 41.6 | Nov rain mm = 6.7 | Dec rain mm = 18.9 | year rain mm = |Jan rain days= 3.8 |Feb rain days= 3.9 |Mar rain days= 2.6 |Apr rain days= 2.4 |May rain days= 2.5 |Jun rain days= 7.1 |Jul rain days= 12.9 |Aug rain days= 13.3 |Sep rain days= 6.1 |Oct rain days= 1.9 |Nov rain days= 1.3 |Dec rain days= 1.9 |source 1= World Meteorological Organisation[http://worldweather.wmo.int/066/c00526.htm World Weather Information Service-Chandigarh], World Meteorological Organisation. Retrieved 29 September 2012. |date=May 2012}} ==Environment== Most of Chandigarh is covered by dense [[banyan]] and [[eucalyptus]] plantations. [[Ashoka tree|Ashoka]], [[Cassia Fistula|cassia]], [[mulberry]] and other trees flourish in the forested ecosystem. The city has forests surrounding that sustain many animal and plant species. [[Deer]], [[Sambar (deer)|sambar]]s, [[barking deer]], parrots, [[woodpecker]]s and [[peacock]]s inhabit the protected forests. [[Sukhna Lake]] hosts a variety of ducks and geese, and attracts migratory birds from parts of Siberia and Japan in the winter season. A parrot sanctuary in the city is home to a variety of bird species. It has popular gardens, e.g. [[Zakir Hussain Rose Garden]], [[Rock Garden of Chandigarh|Rock Garden]], Terrace Garden, Bougainvillea Garden, Shanti Kunj and many others. ==Demographics== {{IndiaCensusPop | title= Chandigarh Population | 1961= 119881 | 1971= 257251 | 1981= 451610 | 1991= 642015 | 2001= 900635 | estimate= | estyear= | estref= | footnote= source:Census of India{{cite web|url=http://sampark.chd.nic.in/images/State_2006/StatisticalAbstract2004/Areapopulation/area_pop_tab2.1.pdf|title=Census population|work=Census of India|publisher=http://sampark.chd.nic.in|accessdate=2008-06-04|format=PDF}} }} {{As of|2011}} India census, Chandigarh had a population of 960,787 with metro population of 1,025,682, making for a density of about 9258 (7900 in 2001) persons per square kilometre.http://www.censusindia.gov.in/{{cite web|url=http://www.ssachd.nic.in/disereport.htm|title=Census observations|work=Census of India|publisher=http://www.ssachd.nic.in}} Males constitute 55% of the population and females 45%. The sex ratio is 829 females for every 1,000 males –which is the lowest in the country,{{citation needed|date=March 2012}} up from 777 in 2001. Chandigarh has an average literacy rate of 86.77%, higher than the national average; with male literacy of 90.81% and female literacy of 81.88%. 10.8% of the population is under 6 years of age. ==Places to Visit== Chandigarh has various visitor attractions including theme gardens within the city. Some notable sites are:{{cite web |url= http://chandigarhtourism.gov.in/Chandigarh%20Tourism%20-%20places%20to%20see.htm|title= Places to See|last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date= |website= chandigarhtourism.gov.in |publisher=Chandigarh Tourism |accessdate=19 March 2014}} * [[Sukhna Lake]] * New Lake, Sector-42 * [[Rock Garden of Chandigarh|Rock garden]], built by [[Nek Chand Saini]] * Leisure valley, Sector-10 * [[Zakir Hussain Rose Garden|Rose Garden]], Sector-16 * Capitol Complex * [[Open Hand Monument|Open hand monument]] * Garden of Silence * [[Cactus garden|Cactus Garden]] * National Gallery of Portraits * Garden of Fragrance * Le Corbusier Centre, Sector-19 * [[Government Museum and Art Gallery, Chandigarh|Government Museum and Art Gallery]], Sector-10 * International Doll Museum * Butterfly Park Several other famous tourist destinations like [[Pinjore Gardens]], [[Morni Hills]], [[Nada Sahib]] lie in its vincity. ==Economy== [[image:Palace of Assembly Chandigarh 2006.jpg|thumb|Legislative Assembly by [[Le Corbusier]]]] [[File:Capitol High Court.jpg|thumb|[[Punjab and Haryana High Court]] by [[Le Corbusier]]]] The RBI ranked Chandigarh as the twelfth largest deposit centre and tenth largest credit centre nationwide as of June 2012. The government is a major employer in Chandigarh with three governments having their base here. A significant percentage of Chandigarh’s population therefore consists of people who are either working for one of these governments or have retired from government service. For this reason, Chandigarh is often called a “Pensioner's Paradise”. Ordnance Cable Factory of the [[Ordnance Factories Board]] has been set up by the [[Government of India]]. There are about 15 medium to large industries including two in the Public sector. In addition Chandigarh has over 2500 units registered under small-scale sector. The important industries are paper manufacturing, basic metals and alloys and machinery. Other industries are relating to food products, sanitary ware, auto parts, machine tools, pharmaceuticals and electrical appliances. Yet, with a per capita income of [[Image:Indian Rupee symbol.svg|8px]] 99,262, Chandigarh is the richest city in India.[http://www.ibnlive.com/news/chandigarhs-the-richest-of-em-all/12571-3.html Chandigarh's the richest of 'em all] Chandigarh's gross state domestic product for 2004 is estimated at $2.2 billion in current prices. Three major trade promotion organisations have their offices in Chandigarh. These are: Federation of Indian Chambers of Commerce & Industry, (FICCI) the PHD Chamber of Commerce and Industry (PHDCCI) and the [[Confederation of Indian Industry]] (CII) which has its regional headquarters at Sector 31, Chandigarh. Chandigarh IT Park (also known as Rajiv Gandhi Chandigarh Technology Park) is the city's attempt to break into the [[information technology]] world. Chandigarh's infrastructure, proximity to [[Delhi]], Haryana, Punjab and [[Himachal Pradesh]], and the IT talent pool attracts IT businesses looking for office space in the area. Major Indian firms and multinational corporations like [[Quark, Inc.|Quark]], [[Infosys]], [[Dell, Inc.|Dell]], [[IBM, Inc.|IBM]], [[TechMahindra]], have set up base in the city and its suburbs. According to a 2014 survey, Chandigarh is ranked 9th in the top 50 cities identified globally as "emerging outsourcing and IT services destinations" ahead of cities like Beijing.[http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/2007/10/03/stories/2007100351450400.htm The Hindu Business Line] ==Education== {{See also|List of educational institutions in Chandigarh}} [[Image:Gandhi Bhawan at Punjab University.jpg|thumbnail|[[Gandhi Bhawan, Chandigarh|Gandhi Bhavan]] built by [[Pierre Jeanneret]] for [[Panjab University]]]] There are numerous education institutions in Chandigarh. These range from privately and publicly operated schools to colleges and the [[Panjab University]]. Other Institutions are [[Post Graduate Institute of Medical Education and Research]] (PGIMER), Govt Medical college & Hospital, Punjab Engineering College Deemed University, Govt College for Men, Govt College for Women, DAV College, [http://www.mcmdavcw-chd.edu/ MCM DAV College for Women], [http://sggscollege.ac.in/ Sri Guru Gobind Singh Khalsa College-26], Govt Homeopathic College, Ayurvedic College, Govt Polytechnical College, Govt Home Science College, Dr Ambedkar Institute of Hotel management etc. These institutions are a large draw for students from around the world.{{cite news|title=City Beautiful|url=http://www.indianbackpacker.com/index.php/india/north/chandigarh-city-beautiful|accessdate=2 January 2013|newspaper=The Indian Backpacker|date=December 2012}} According to Chandigarh administration's department of education, there are a total of 107 government schools in Chandigarh.{{cite web|title=Department of Education|url=http://www.chdeducation.gov.in/schoolslist.asp}} ==Transport== [[File:Chandigarh Airport - mural.jpg|thumb|Chandigarh Airport from inside]] Chandigarh has the largest number of vehicles per capita in India.[http://www.mapsofindia.com/top-ten-cities-of-india/top-ten-highest-no-of-car-ownership.html Top Ten Towns with Highest Nos. of Car Ownership in India] Wide, well maintained roads and parking spaces all over the city ease local transport. The [[Chandigarh Transport Undertaking]] (CTU) operates public transport buses from its Inter State Bus Terminals (ISBT) in Sectors 17 and 43 of the city.[http://chdctu.gov.in/ISBT.aspx Chandigarh Transport Undertaking ISBT] CTU also operates frequent bus services to the neighbouring states of [[Punjab region|Punjab]], [[Haryana]], [[Himachal Pradesh]] and to [[Delhi]]. Chandigarh is well connected by road by [[National Highway 22 (India) |NH 22]] (Ambala - Kalka - [[Shimla]] - [[Khab]], Kinnaur) and [[National Highway 21 (India) |NH 21]] (Chandigarh - [[Leh]]). [[Chandigarh railway station]] lies in the [[Northern Railway zone]] of the [[Indian Railway]] network and provide connectivity to major Indian cities like [[Delhi]], [[Mumbai]], [[Kolkata]], [[Visakhapatnam]], [[Jaipur]], [[Lucknow]], [[Bhopal]], [[Indore]], [[Trivandrum]] and [[Amritsar]]. It also links other cities like [[Ambala]], [[Kollam]], [[Panipat]] and [[Kalka]]. [[Chandigarh Airport]] has scheduled commercial flights to major cities of India including [[Indira Gandhi International Airport|Delhi]], [[Chatrapati Shivaji International Airport|Mumbai]], [[Indore]], [[Jaipur]] and [[Srinagar]]. A new international terminal is under construction. Flights are available to [[Bhuntar Airport|Kullu-Manali]] also with Himalayan Bulls. The [[Chandigarh Metro|Chandigarh Metro Rail]] is a proposed metro rail to serve the city and expected to start working by 2018 along with the extension of [[Kolkata Metro]] and proposed [[Indore Metro]]. ==Entertainment== ===Sports=== Chandigarh is home to numerous inter state sporting teams like [[Kings XI Punjab]] in The [[Indian Premier League]] (IPL). ===Gardens=== It also has two gardens of international repute – the [[Rock Garden of Chandigarh]] in sector 1 and the [[Zakir Hussain Rose Garden]] in sector 16. The latter has the distinction of being the largest of its kind in Asia. ===Communications=== If we talk about internet connectivity it is most important to know ISP companies in chandigarh. internet plays an important role in entertaining us. Available internet providers are; Airtel Broadband, Connect Broadband, Tata photon & 3G wireless internet, BSNL broadband,z26z broadband, Reliance DSL or 1a1.in USB modem type, Airtel 4G wifi. Same ISPs are serving in [[Sehzada Ajit Singh nagar]] & Panchkula (other two cities of the [[Chandigarh Tricity]]). ==Notable people from Chandigarh== *[[Kirron Kher]], Indian actress and theatre artist (also BJP M.P.) *[[Milkha Singh]] Commonwealth gold medalist. ''[[Bhaag Milkha Bhaag]]'' is a 2013 film based on his life.
